astounded: Very surprised or shocked by something, because it seems very unlikely
apparently: Used when the real situation is different from what you thought it was
attached to: To attach a particular quality to something is to consider it to have that quality
appraised: To examine someone or something in order to judge their qualities, success, or needs
alas: Used to express sadness or feeling sorry about something
accentuated: To emphasize a particular feature of something or to make something more noticeable
anxieties: Something that causes a feeling of fear and worry
boon: Something that is very helpful and improves the quality of life
bead:
A small piece of glass, wood, etc. with a hole through it, that can be put on a string
with others of the same type and worn as jewelry, etc.
brimming:
? The top edge of a cup, bowl, glass, etc.
? fill or be full to the point of overflowing
baffling: To cause someone to be completely unable to understand or explain something:
beckoned: To move your hand or head in a way that tells someone to come nearer:
credentials:
Documents that state the abilities and experience of a person and show that the person is qualified for a particular job or
activity:
capacious: Having a lot of space and able to contain a lot:
collided with: to come together with solid or direct impact
confront: To face, meet, or deal with a difficult situation or person:
compelled: Having to do something, because you are forced to or feel it is necessary:
crudely:
? In a simple way that is not very accurate but gives a general idea of something
? In an offensive or rude way
coaxed:
To persuade someone gently to do
something or go somewhere, by being kind and patient, or by appearing to be:
comprehension: The ability to understand completely and be familiar with a situation, facts, etc.
curious: Interested in learning about people or things around you:
casually: Casual clothes are not formal or not suitable for special occasions:
confining: To limit an activity, person, or problem in some way:
crammed: Very full of people or things:
confirm: To make an arrangement or meeting certain, often by phone or writing:
captivated: To hold the attention of someone by being extremely interesting, exciting, pleasant, or attractive:
condescended:
? to do something that you think it is below your social or professional position to do
? to behave towards somebody as though you are more important and more intelligent than they are
criteria: A principle or standard by which something may be judged or decided.
daintily:
In an attractive, careful way, especially
used about something small or having small movements:
dispute:
An argument or disagreement, especially an official one between, for example, workers and employers or two countries
with a common border:
distract: To make someone stop giving their attention to something:
drummed:
A musical instrument, especially one made from a skin stretched over the end of a
hollow tube or bowl, played by hitting with the hand or a stick:
delicately: Needing careful treatment, especially because easily damaged:
dank: (especially of buildings and air) wet, cold, and unpleasant:
disguise:
To give a new appearance to a person or thing, especially in order to hide its true
form:
dispensing:
? To give out things, especially products, services, or amounts of money:
? to prepare medicine and give it to people, as a job
enchanted: Affected by magic or seeming to be
encouraged: Having more confidence or hope about something:
exude:
If you exude love, confidence, pain, etc., you show that you have a lot of that
feeling:
eccentric: Strange or unusual, sometimes in a humorous way:
excursion: A short journey usually made for pleasure, often by a group of people:
elaborate: Containing a lot of careful detail or many detailed parts:
exasperation: The feeling of being annoyed, especially because you can do nothing to solve a problem:
expansive: ? covering a large amount of space
exaggeration:
To make something seem larger, more important, better, or worse than it really
is:
evaluates: To judge or calculate the quality, importance, amount, or value of something:
fatality:
A death caused by an accident or by
violence, or someone who has died in either of these ways:
flicked: To move or hit something with a short sudden movement:
flawlessly: In a way that is perfect or without mistakes:
friction:
The force that makes it difficult for one object to slide along the surface of another
or to move through a liquid or gas:
fluttered:
To make a series of quick delicate
movements up and down or from side to side, or to cause something to do this:
gingerly: in a careful or cautious manner.
glistening: To shine by reflecting light from a wet or smooth surface:
fringed: Having a strip of hanging threads attached along the edge for decoration
glared: a very bright, unpleasant light A long, angry look:
groggy:
Weak and unable to think clearly or walk
correctly, usually because of tiredness or illness:
heap: An untidy pile or mass of things:
habitat: The natural environment in which an animal or plant usually lives
haggard: Looking ill or tired, often with dark skin under the eyes:
haphazardly: In a way that does not have an obvious order or plan:
harmony: A pleasant musical sound made by different notes being played or sung at the same time:
haughty: Unfriendly and seeming to consider yourself better than other people:
hearsay: Information that you have heard but do not know to be true:
havoc: Confusion and lack of order, especially causing damage or trouble:
intended: The person that you are going to marry:
illumination: coloured decorative lights outside that make a town look bright and exciting at night:
insinuated: To suggest, without being direct, that something unpleasant is true:
intently: In a way that gives all your attention to something:
industry:
The companies and activities involved in
the process of producing goods for sale, especially in a factory or special area:
intolerable: too bad or unpleasant to deal with or accept:
imperceptibly: Unable to be noticed or felt because of being very slight:
judgment:
A decision or opinion about someone or
something that you form after thinking carefully:
junction: A place where things, especially roads or railways, come together:
juvenile: Relating to a young person who is not yet old enough to be considered an adult:
jeopardy: In danger of being damaged or destroyed:
jealousy: A feeling of unhappiness and anger because someone has something or someone that you want:
jubilant: Feeling or expressing great happiness, especially because of a success:
knack: A skill or an ability to do something easily and well:
knickers: Short loose trousers that fit tightly below the knee, worn especially in the past
knickknack: A small, decorative object, esp. in a house:
likelihood: The chance that something will happen:
labyrinth: A confusing set of connecting passages or paths in which it is easy to get lost:
ludicrous: Stupid or unreasonable and deserving to be laughed at:
limp: To walk slowly and with difficulty because of having an injured or painful leg or foot:
menaced: A dangerous quality that makes you think someone is going to do something bad:
mustered: To produce or encourage something such as an emotion or support:
mean: To express or represent something such as an idea, thought, or fact:
mass:
having an effect on or involving a large
number of people or forming a large amount:
minimum: The smallest amount or number allowed or possible:
mayhem: A situation in which there is little or no order or control:
miniature: Used to describe something that is a very small copy of an object:
mumbled: To speak quietly and in a way that is not clear so that the words are difficult to understand:
moulded: A soft, green or grey growth that develops on old food or on objects that have been left for too long in warm, wet air:
meditated: To think calm thoughts in order to relax or as a religious activity:
nuisance: Something or someone that annoys you or causes trouble for you:
naive: Too willing to believe that someone is telling the truth, that people's intentions in general are good, or that life is simple and fair.
native: Relating to or describing someone's country or place of birth or someone who was born in a particular country or place:
negate: To cause something to have no effect:
negligence: the fact of not giving enough care or attention to someone or something:
nemesis: (A cause of) punishment or defeat that is deserved and cannot be avoided:
neutral: not saying or doing anything that would encourage or help any of the groups involved in an argument or war:
niggle: to worry someone slightly, usually for a long time:
opted for: To make a choice, especially of one thing or possibility instead of others:
on the wrong\nfoot: To begin badly, especially to begin a relationship badly.
operation: the fact of operating or being active:
plopped: Flapping sound of an object dropping in a liquid.
presume: To believe something to be true because it is very likely, although you are not certain:
precautions: An action that is done to prevent something unpleasant or dangerous happening:
panting: To breathe quickly and loudly through your mouth, usually because you have been doing something very energetic:
persisted: If an unpleasant feeling or situation persists, it continues to exist:
pensively: In a way that shows that you are thinking in a quiet way, often with a serious expression on your face:
peered: To look carefully or with difficulty:
propelling: To push or move something somewhere, often with a lot of force:
passion: A very powerful feeling, for example of sexual attraction, love, hate, anger, or other emotion:
paraphernalia: All the objects needed for or connected with a particular activity:
prerogative:
Something that certain people are able or
allowed to do or have, but is not possible or allowed for everyone:
path:
A route or track between one place and another, or the direction in which something is
moving:
potential: Possible when the necessary conditions exist:
pizzazz: The quality of noticeable and energetic excitement:
qualitative: Relating to how good or bad something is:
qualm: An uncomfortable feeling when you doubt if you are doing the right thing:
quarrel: An angry disagreement between two or more people or groups:
quench: To drink liquid so that you stop being thirsty:
query:
A question, often expressing doubt about
something or looking for an answer from an authority:
queue: A line of people, usually standing or in cars, waiting for something:
quirk:
An unusual habit or part of someone's personality, or something that is strange and
unexpected:
quiver: To shake slightly, often because of strong emotion:
quizzical: Seeming to ask a question without saying anything:
quotation: A phrase or short piece of writing taken from a longer work of literature, poetry, etc. or what someone else has said:
rituals:
A set of fixed actions and sometimes words
performed regularly, especially as part of a ceremony:
reinforce:
If something reinforces an idea or opinion, it
provides more proof or support for it and makes it seem true:
reprimanded: To express to someone your strong official disapproval of them:
riot:
An occasion when a large number of people
behave in a noisy, violent, and uncontrolled way in public, often as a protest:
reluctantly: In a way that shows that you are not willing to do something and are therefore slow to do it:
refuge: A place that gives) protection or shelter from danger, trouble, unhappiness, etc.:
regret:
A feeling of sadness about something sad or wrong or about a mistake that you have made, and a wish that it could have been different
and better:
ragged: (Of clothes) torn and not in good condition:
revolving: Able to turn in a circle, moving round
resonant: Clear and loud, or causing sounds to be clear and loud:
scenario: plot, outline, storyline, framework, structure, scheme, plan, layout
swathe: a broad strip or area of something.
subsequently: Afterwards; later; after something else has happened
struck up: To start to play or sing something:
string: (A piece of) strong, thin rope made by twisting very thin threads together, used for fastening and tying things:
shuffled: To walk by pulling your feet slowly along the ground rather than lifting them: Shuffle the cards and deal out seven to each player.
sailed: When a boat or a ship sails, it travels on the water:
stunt:
An exciting action, usually in a film, that is dangerous or appears dangerous and usually needs to be done by someone
skilled:
sauntered: To walk in a slow and relaxed way, often in no particular direction:
splendour: Great beauty that attracts admiration and attention:
stable: Firmly fixed or not likely to move or change:
tentatively: In a way that shows you are not certain or confident:
tackle: To try to deal with something or someone:
tumultuous: A loud noise, especially that produced by an excited crowd, or a state of confusion, change, or uncertainty:
tomfoolery: Silly behaviour, especially done as a joke
tangle: To mess up things that are not in a state of order, or a state of confusion or difficulty:
troughs: A long, narrow container without a lid that usually holds water or food for farm animals:
tangled: An untidy mass of things that are not in a state of order, or a state of confusion or difficulty:
urge: A strong wish, especially one that is difficult or impossible to control:
unburdened:
To free yourself of something that is
worrying you, by talking about it to someone:
unprovoked: If an unpleasant action or remark is unprovoked, it has not been caused by anything and is therefore unfair:
ventured: A new activity, usually in business, that involves risk or uncertainty:
vulnerable: Able to be easily physically, emotionally, or mentally hurt, influenced, or attacked:
whipped: A piece of leather or rope that is fastened to a stick, used for hitting animals or people:
weighing up: To think carefully about the advantages or disadvantages of a situation before making a decision:
writhing: To make large twisting movements with the body:
waft: To (cause to) move gently through the air:
yearning: A strong feeling of wishing for something, especially something that you cannot have or get easily:
yelp: To make a sudden, short, high sound, usually when in pain:
yield:
To supply or produce something positive
such as a profit, an amount of food or information:
zenith: The best or most successful point or time:
